questions.question_text:
Your on-premises network contains the web applications shown in the following table.
//IMG//

You purchase Microsoft 365, and then implement directory synchronization.
You plan to publish the web applications.
You need to ensure that all the applications are accessible by using the My Apps portal. The solution must minimize administrative effort.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/app-proxy/application-proxy-connectors
The Application Proxy connector is what connects the on-premises environment to the Azure Application Proxy.

Selected Answer: B
You need the proxy to connect the onprem apps to AzureAD.
Seen simular questions before.

Selected Answer: B
B. Deploy one Application Proxy connector.

Selected Answer: B
they are on prem so first of all you need the proxy connector

comments.content: eh you want to register the apps in AAD without being able to connect to them?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C for sure!

choices.D: Create a site-to-site VPN from Microsoft Azure to the on-premises network.

questions.question_text:
You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription.
All users are assigned a license to Microsoft 365 Apps for enterprise.
The users report that they do not have the option to install Microsoft 365 apps on their device as shown in the following exhibit.
//IMG//

You need to ensure that the users can install Microsoft 365 apps from the Office 365 portal.
What should you do?

discussion.content: Settings > Org Settings >Services > Office installation options, to be precise.

comments.content: Agree with you, the answers look like not up to date
yes makes sense, also if you do not have the license would you even see the apps to begin with?
Yes thats right, the answer given is misleading.

discussion.content:
seems like microsoft likes changing the path, here is the newest one:
Admin Center > Settings > Org settings > Services > Microsoft 365 installation options > Installation

Choose Microsoft apps that users can install on their own devices

Selected Answer: D
What lucidgreen says. 
It's possible to deploy the apps using endpoint manager but thats not what is asked for.
The users need to be able to install themselves by logging in to the portal.
This has to be enabled first.
Seen before in other questions.

Selected Answer: D
Settings >> Org settings >> Office installation options >> Installation "tab" >> Office apps that users can install >> "Choose whether your users can install Office apps on their own devices."

M365 admin center link:
https://admin.microsoft.com/Adminportal/Home#/Settings/Services/:/Settings/L1/SoftwareDownload


https://admin.microsoft.com/Adminportal/Home#/Settings/Services/:/Settings/L1/SoftwareDownload
Was in my exam today 05/08/22.

Selected Answer: D
https://admin.microsoft.com/Adminportal/Home#/Settings/Services/:/Settings/L1/SoftwareDownload
This question was in my exam on 06/April/2022. I passed.
Hi, so what is the answer, please?Thanks

in a normal setting, this is automatically enabled, you have to think of this i see as a fresh setup that is rather custom to this company. Anytime i add a E5 license the option to install has always been there.
If you user has basic licenses (basic licenses only gives you online version of the office) then they need to change the licenses to standard or premium to install the office on thier devices

comments.content: Read the 1st line: You have a Microsoft 365 E5 subscription. - This is not basic licenses

choices.D: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, modify the Services settings.
choices.C: From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center, create a Microsoft 365 Apps app and assign the app to the users.
choices.A: From the Microsoft 365 admin center, modify the user license settings.
choices.B: From the Microsoft Endpoint Manager admin center, create a Microsoft 365 Apps app and assign the app to the devices.

questions.answer_description:
A cutover migration and an IMAP migration do not require the company to sync the on-premises Active Directory domain to Microsoft Azure Active Directory
(Azure AD). Only a cutover migration meets the requirements in this question.
With a cutover migration, user accounts will need to be created in Azure Active Directory for each user. The mailboxes are all migrated in one go and MX records configured to redirect email to Microsoft 365.
Incorrect Answers:
B: Contacts, calendar items and tasks cannot be migrated with an IMAP migration.
C: A remote move migration requires a hybrid exchange configuration which requires that the on-premises Active Directory domain is synced to Microsoft Azure
Active Directory (Azure AD).
D: A staged migration is recommended when your source email system is Microsoft Exchange Server 2003 or Microsoft Exchange Server 2007. You can't use a staged migration to migrate Exchange 2013 or Exchange 2010 mailboxes to Office 365. A staged migration also requires that the on-premises Active Directory domain is synced to Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mailbox-migration/cutover-migration-to-office-365 https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mailbox-migration/what-to-know-about-a-staged-migration

discussion.content: A maximum of 2,000 mailboxes can be migrated to Microsoft 365 or Office 365 by using a cutover Exchange migration. However, it is recommended that you only migrate 150 mailboxes.

Answer is correct. Cutover migration is best for scenarios with under 2,000 Exchange mailboxes and a non-hybrid Exchange environment (this scenario is migrating to Exchange Online from Exchange on-premises.

Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/exchange/mailbox-migration/cutover-migration-to-office-365

Selected Answer: A
A: cutover

Selected Answer: A
Answer A is correct
Cutover migration!

questions.question_text:
Your company has an on-premises Microsoft Exchange Server 2013 organization.
The company has 100 users.
The company purchases Microsoft 365 and plans to move its entire infrastructure to the cloud.
The company does NOT plan to sync the on-premises Active Directory domain to Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You need to recommend which type of migration to use to move all email messages, contacts, and calendar items to Exchange Online.
What should you recommend?

comments.content:
Agreed with this.
More specifications can be found here: 
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-user

Confirm. The answer is correct. You can see :https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-user https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenant}/oauth2/v2.0/authorize?
client_id=6731de76-14a6-49ae-97bc-6eba6914391e
&response_type=code
&redirect_uri=http%3A%2F%2Flocalhost%2Fmyapp%2F
&response_mode=query
&scope=offline_access%20user.read%20mail.read
&state=12345

discussion.content:
In a single tenant application, sign-in requests are sent to the tenant’s sign-in endpoint. For example, for contoso.onmicrosoft.com the endpoint would be: https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
Ref: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/howto-convert-app-to-be-multi-tenant#update-your-code-to-send-requests-to-common
On exam today

Selected Answer: C
Thought A initially but will go with the answer and explanation provided C

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer.
This question was in my exam on 06/April/2022. I passed.

C
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth-v2-user
 The {tenant} value in the path of the request can be used to control who can sign into the application. The allowed values are common for both Microsoft accounts and work or school accounts, organizations for work or school accounts only, consumers for Microsoft accounts only, and tenant identifiers such as the tenant ID or domain name. For more detail, see protocol basics.

This then refers you to check the protocols:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/active-directory-v2-protocols#endpoints

C is correct. A is tricky
https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com/ - works for users of that tenant
https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/ - works for any users of any tenant
C for sure!

correct answer is A
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/graph/auth/auth-concepts

comments.content: It's Alexander Saad, not Alexander Said

discussion.content:
As Alexander Said 
The C answer is correct :
In a single tenant application, sign-in requests are sent to the tenant’s sign-in endpoint. For example, for contoso.onmicrosoft.com the endpoint would be: https://login.microsoftonline.com/contoso.onmicrosoft.com
from
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/howto-convert-app-to-be-multi-tenant#update-your-code-to-send-requests-to-common
A is the correct answer. The login URL for apps is https://login.microsoftonline.com/" followed by tenant iD and tokens
I don't think C is the answer. I leaning toward D.

questions.question_text:
Your network contains an Active Directory domain named contoso.com.
You have a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You have a Microsoft Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tenant named contoso.onmicrosoft.com.
You implement directory synchronization.
The developers at your company plan to build an app named App1. App1 will connect to the Microsoft Graph API to provide access to several Microsoft Office 365 services.
You need to provide the URI for the authorization endpoint that App1 must use.
What should you provide?

DRAG DROP -
Your company has a hybrid deployment of Azure Active Directory (Azure AD).
You purchase a Microsoft 365 subscription.
You plan to migrate the Home folder of each user to Microsoft 365 during several weeks. Each user has a device that runs Windows 10.
You need to recommend a solution to migrate the Home folder of five administrative users as quickly as possible.
Which three actions should you recommend be performed in sequence? To answer, move the appropriate actions from the list of actions to the answer area and arrange them in the correct order.
Select and Place:
//IMG//
questions.answer_description:
You need to configure a Group Policy Object (GPO) with the OneDrive settings required to redirect the Home folder of each user to Microsoft 365.
Before you can configure the Group Policy, you need to download the OneDrive Administrative Templates. These templates add the required OneDrive settings to Group Policy so you can configure the settings as required.
After the OneDrive settings have been configured in Group Policy, you can run the gpupdate /force command on the five computers to apply the new Group Policy settings immediately.
Reference:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/onedrive/use-group-policy

discussion.content: In exam today
I just CBA with this question. Haha. see what i did there.
BDA, I would say...

DBA I suppose!
Please correct if I am wrong

comments.content: Home Folder is not the same as Folder Redirection. Home Folder you can configure from AD account - Profile tab.

That's not correct - it can work, unless the known folders aren't redirected to be nested (e.g. Pictures is located in Documents). For nested home folders the Folder Redirection settings have to be changed first for the GPO to work.

discussion.content: "Copy the Onedrive administrative template to your computer" is wrong. Assuming that the Home Folder is located on a File Server and a folder redirection GPO is applied to user devices to redirect home folders to the file server. So you need first change the Folder Redirection GPO to remove redirection to the file server, than create the new Onedrive GPO, finally instruct users to run gpupdate: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/onedrive/redirect-known-folders#transition-from-the-windows-folder-redirection-group-policy-objects
Afterwards you need to use the sharepoint migration tool to migrate the files on the home folders to OneDrive, no? Why is it not in the answers?

comments.content: You'll need to run the SPMT for each user. I'd question why using the OneDrive known folders move isn't ine the list of answers, as that'll be much quicker.
The GPO setting that step 2 is about is implementing the Known Folder Move. So it is mentioned. :-)

discussion.content: For some reason you need to copy the amdx files from your local computer to the sysvol folder... the answer may be not completely correct.. thats were u start.. so it makes sort of sense

"Copy OneDrive Administrative Templates to your computer" - doesnt make any sense, just copying admx files doesnt do a thing, you need to also place is under \\yourdomainname\sysvol\domain\Policies\PolicyDefinitions

comments.content: You can copy the ADMX templates to PolicyDefinitions on your local computer then start GPMC to configure OneDrive settings. No need to copy to the CentralStore first.

In production environment this would be prefered solution - use Central Store to store admx files (you can manage GPO from any computer - no need to copy them to all workstations you want to modify GPO settings)
but as zorro1 wrote we have no such answer.

That's not an available answer. So copying makes most sense.
Answer looks reasonable to me.
